WRITING.TEXT: Well, there's not much more advice to be doled out, that really boxes in the amount of response you can get. Upgrading ram from 8gb to 16gb helped me quite a bit, I have a ton of mods as well, but I don't know if that is an option for you either. 8 might be the max for your motherboard. And even so, it won't do the magic the way a graphics card upgrade would.

This is gonna be one of those deaths I think I'll remember forever. The news is deeply etched into my brain. My family was going to eat at Shoney's and we'd just pulled into the parking lot when the news came on the radio. It was the short bullet point news announcements in between programs and they led bluntly with "Chris Farley is dead..." And I was sure they were going to say something like, "..is dead tired of making movies." But no luck, there wasn't much info right then, just found dead. It was a pretty crummy dinner, even crummier than any other meal at Shoney's, I mean.
That death is tied with learning about Phil Hartman after I came home from school and was watching SNL reruns on Comedy Central. It was a rough year for comedy fans.

This foolishness has to stop. Quit trying to deny the world of Karch.
There are a dozen of Ns on the board, all exactly the same. No stems of varying heights. Only one time does a stem become an ascender...the final letter in Karch. There are just as many Es to examine and compare, each has a distinct loop. And there is absolutely no loop to be seen in the penultimate letter in Karch.

Sorry, many others have posited that, but it is not the case...
"Negativo. You can see many more lower case Ns among the other names. Mason, Peyton, TWO Nolans..it's an embarrassment of Ns. And they are all consistently made, the final letter in Karch/Karen is different and so unmistakably an H, no N on the board has a stem that ascends above the x-height."
I was thrown off too, not keeping up with Piper at all outside of Doctor Who, she was hard for me to recognize this many years later and with darker hair.
"We are out of Bort license plates! I repeat, out of Bort license plates.."

Nope,I debunked it in another reply.
"Negativo. You can see many more lower case Ns among the other names. Mason, Peyton, TWO Nolans..it's an embarrassment of Ns. And they are all consistently made, the final letter in Karch/Karen is different and so unmistakably an H, no N on the board has a stem that ascends above the x-height."

Negativo. You can see many more lower case Ns among the other names. Mason, Peyton, TWO Nolans..it's an embarrassment of Ns. And they are all consistently made, the final letter in Karch/Karen is different and so unmistakably an H, no N on the board has a stem that ascends above the x-height.

My parents had a subscription growing up and I always loved the map issues. I lost track of the magazine after I moved out and was very excited when I got a subscription for my birthday this year, but the excitement was greatly tempered when I noticed the first couple issues had no maps and further research showed that maps had slowly turned into just pull-outs/posters and then pull-outs/posters slowly turned into nothing. :(
I used to get so excited to see the red text on the spine every other month.

He doesn't really seem to have "an ear" for great screenplays. And in general, he seems to be a more casual movie fan that's happy to eat popcorn and be distracted for a couple hours rather than be really analytical and discerning of the medium. As in the case of The Shining, he doesn't fully appreciate that movies and books are different and may need different approaches..so he had a fairly bland, largely forgotten, but by the book!, TV adaptation made to appease him.
I wouldn't flatly say this is absolutely a *bad* omen, it's just kinda non-information...of course he's going to be happy with the screenplay cause he's been happy with just about every screenplay. We've really gained no confidence in the project by hearing this.

It'd be a great effect to see in game, for sure. The problem seems to be a kinda "simplification" of the landscape materials. The land is a bit too hard to sculpt to creek level of details, like trying to carve fine details into clay while wearing gloves. Maybe not impossible, but there's definitely somewhat of a barrier from terraforming at this small of a resolution.
Maybe more of the culprit is the water though, which doesn't quite have the viscosity of real world water and feels thicker, more like shampoo. Again, for lack of a better word, the "resolution" just isn't small enough to allow it to flow through thin cracks and crevasses
Anything that could shine and glint like that, even in a tiny way, could be like putting a spotlight on yourself for an opposing sniper looking for any small indication of a potential target.

Some stores, Kohl's comes to mind as I just heard it two days ago, when they give you the receipt and tell you about their annoying survey that you'll never take have started saying, "If you'd take this survey and give us all 5s and 'very satisfied' we'd really appreciate it!"
Yeah, thanks, I'm sure you would. I understand numbers and varying degrees of customer satisfaction quantification, I can handle the rest after you say, "Here's a survey". Why don't you not bother me with your nonsense and just stuff the ballot with thousands of fake 5s if you're gonna tell me explicitly how to take it.

Oh I can definitely get that, I only take every good opportunity to rag on the show. Nothing against your point. I see what you're saying, it's one thing to fail to doing something and another to go out of your way to do something the wrong way.
It's amazing with a show this smart and carefully planned, this well written and acted, this gripping and suspenseful that some mistakes managed to sneak in its impeccable production.

Cool, hopefully this might all be somewhat helpful. First, [here's a quick crop](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B87bLR2Jh090X0p6V2U2SjJPTEE/view?usp=sharing) of the map after I adjusted the layers some to more closely match Google Maps, just to show that you can get that more minimalist look easily, if that's more what you're driving towards. If you've got some familiarity with Photoshop, it's simple to mess around with the layer styles and see what looks good to you.
[Here are the brushes](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B87bLR2Jh090eW5sTkQ3X1Z6eTQ/view?usp=sharing) I made. The House brush is pretty basic, just a rectangle that has a spacing setting and a small size and position jitter to add some variety. Just draw alongside your roads to easily lay down rows of homes. The settings are made for the scale of my map, so it might be small for your needs and could necessitate increasing the spacing as you increase the actual brush size to fit your map. The Tree brushes are the same, spacing with some size jitter. The dashed line brush I've used for designating neighborhoods or drawing paths traveled. The road brushes aren't anything special, I only made them to quickly be able to reference their sizes. The way I made roads was by using paths, I'd draw a path with the pen tool and then stroke that path. So if I wanted a two-lane road I could easily pick out that road brush in my palette and stroke the path so it's the proper thickness. Or a different brush to draw a highway..or a walking path, make sense? Saves some time from remembering what your brush size needs to be and always toggling the size up and down as you work on different elements.
And [here are the styles](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B87bLR2Jh090Q253SlNNbGVtbGc/view?usp=sharing) I've been using. Set up separate layers for each aspect-roads, buildings, trees, water and apply these styles and then you just draw on the right layers and you've easily added new elements that have a consistent look that's always easy to universally modify down the road if you should wish.
Hopefully all that is easy to follow, I don't share my tools and techniques much, so I'm not used to explaining and instructing how to use them and so might accidentally skip some steps in between or not be fully explicit on how I achieved certain things. Let me know how it goes.

Man, I started a city map a year and a half or so ago and I was in the same boat. Tons of help and programs geared towards fantasy or larger scale geographic maps, but not a whole lot out there on creating a modern map. I believe with QGIS or ArcGIS there was a convoluted way to make fictional maps but it seemed like a hassle. Eventually I just resigned myself to do it without any helping hands in Photoshop.
I was able to work out a good enough system for my needs though using layer styles and custom brushes and paths. So it still feels dynamic and pretty easy to tweak on a global scale..if I want to change the color of buildings or thicken the stroke on the roads, for some examples. [Here's a little section](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B87bLR2Jh090eTYzNnNhQ1JuTjg/view?usp=sharing) of my map to show the look. As much as I'd love to make it look just like a satellite image, I think this is a nice fun level of detail without making me go insane and wanting to kill myself over the tedium. :D
If Photoshop is an option for you and this approach is appealing I could help you get started and give you some of my custom tools.

Not that you aren't wrong about the vibe of the show regardless. I just rewatched the series with my girlfriend over the course of just a few weeks and it's really jarring to go from seasons 1-3 to 7-9 so quickly. Subtlety, dreadful awkwardness, sadness, low key, realistic storylines...bye bye. The show suffered from major Flandersization.
I think one of the worst single ideas you can easily point at is stringing as along with Erin and Andy(a pairing which was never Jim and Pam no matter how much they wanted it to be) for two seasons just to have him be dumped for good shortly after. Thanks for wasting all our investment on a story that was already sub-par from the beginning.

I'm happy to have any Sherlock, but this has always bummed me out a bit too. Something like this is fun when it's..one Treehouse of Horror episode a season or whatever...but when production is constantly like moving mountains, this feels kind of like a waste of the talent's precious time. I suppose I could see it being interpreted by some that way, but I don't think most would. Anecdotally, but I've never heard or read anyone mention it with the intention to mock it, but being curious about it in the same way it's fun to see audition tapes or hear early casting news on such an iconic film and imagining "what if". And this is just a very unique case where our peek into this alternate universe isn't limited to an unspectacular few minutes reading from a script in an office but having half a film to enjoy.

I'm not really holding my breath. They hyped it up somewhat for the first blu-ray release and then it ended up being basically nothing. I was gonna say that they might be withholding it to have an incentive to buy yet another release in the future..and Bob Gale confirmed that line of thinking. But I don't know what they're waiting for if not the big high-def release or the 30th anniversary coinciding with the actual movie's timeline.
I think it would've been smarter just to make a truly definitive feeling collection rather than counting on the most die-hardest of fans, the only ones interested in Eric Stoltz's footage, jumping at a third, if we're lucky...but maybe the fourth or fifth, cash grab release in the future. After being jerked around for years, I don't know if the interest will overcome the apathy and frustration.

I've admittedly not had a ton of mechanic visits, so I might not know all the ins and outs, but it's common practice to strip your car of everything not bolted down before dropping it off? I really doubt it. He has talked about how he doesn't have the endings of most books in mind when starting out, so I can't imagine he had a strong framework for ending a series in 30 years. Most probably could've and didn't want to or feel motivated to. It wasn't the movement at the time. You could say the same thing about a dozen other eras and artists. Why didn't Picasso do this? Why didn't Monet? Why didn't Degas?
Photorealism isn't the peak of creative/technical achievement that every artist since a neanderthal put a charred stick to a cave has aspired to.

Happy I could help, I remember back in the olden days, looking up Comedy Central's schedule and vigilantly watching out for episodes so I could rewatch my favorite sketches or catch recurring ones I hadn't seen before. Even ordering home-recorded VHS tapes to find them.
